title: GRA Unhappy With Abuse Of Permits
text:
20 July 2015 16:49 CET GRA Unhappy With Abuse Of Permits By Daily Guide 
The Customs Division of the Ghana Revenue Authority (GRA) has expressed dismay over the continuous abuse of the temporary importation permit granted to citizens in the Economic Community of West Africa (ECOWAS) countries. 
Maxwell Ohemeng, a Senior Revenue Collecting Officer at the Customs Division of GRA, told Ghana News Agency on the sidelines of a stakeholders meeting in Takoradi that the law permits ECOWAS citizens to enter Ghana with their private vehicles to transact businesses for a period of three months without paying any duties on them. 
â€œHowever, some unscrupulous persons have taken advantage of the system to enter the country with vehicles and sell them cheaper to innocent buyers before the three months period,' he added. 
Mr Ohemeng noted that since such vehicles were not customized and lacked the relevant documentation, they end up being seized by officials of GRA and those who purchase those vehicles often pay penalty as well as duties. 
Mr Ohemeng therefore urged prospective vehicle buyers to conduct thorough checks with the GRA to establish the ownership and authenticity of the documents covering any vehicle before purchase to avert being defrauded. 
He noted that those vehicles often bore foreign number plates, however, people who have the intention to defraud others often change the number plates into fictitious local plates and sell them. 
The officer also lamented about the country's porous entry points and stressed the need to monitor the borders to prevent such vehicles from entering the country. 
Mr. Ohemeng advised importers to avoid importing vehicles that were over 10 years old in view of the high duties and penalties they attract. 
He said the Customs Division of the GRA has been working with INTERPOL to track stolen vehicles and assured the public that those who provide vital information to the security agencies would be rewarded. 
GNA
